description: From Middle English bryngen, from Old English bringan, from Proto-West Germanic *bringan, from Proto-Germanic *bringaną (“to bring”),  from Proto-Indo-European *bʰrenk-, possibly based on *bʰer-.

Compare West Frisian bringe, Low German bringen, Dutch brengen, German bringen; also Welsh hebrwng (“to bring, lead”), Tocharian B pränk- (“to take away; restrain oneself, hold back”), Latvian brankti (“lying close”), Lithuanian branktas (“whiffletree”).

verbs.description: bring (third-person singular simple present brings, present participle bringing, simple past and past participle brought)

examples: Waiter, please bring me a single malt whiskey.
The new company director brought a fresh perspective on sales and marketing.
The controversial TV broadcast brought a storm of complaints.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To raise (a lawsuit, charges, etc.) against somebody.
To persuade; to induce; to draw; to lead; to guide.
To produce in exchange; to sell for; to fetch.
examples: What does coal bring per ton?

entries.meaning: (baseball) To pitch, often referring to a particularly hard thrown fastball.
examples: The closer Jones can really bring it.
